bibl.note: This is a letter dated June 12, 1845. The author is unknown, but is writing to a brother named Robert. The author describes a recent business trip. He writes about the people he has seen. He is pleased with his trip, but did not accomplish much on it. The author also mentions how well his rye and wheat crops are doing.

div1.p:
I received yours dated the 3rd may after riting to you before I now have little of intrest to you On the 21 May being at a loss to now how to git along well determined to make a hard trial to sell the Turell Place and Hugh Kirkpatrick Snr had bean talking some about buying my first trial was with him and that wold take me 7 or 8 days to me I thot verry hard work started and got to Franklen the first mile and after enquiring I could here of but thre persons that I new and did not se them on the 22 pased Columbia and sean some of that butiful country due west and got to William Ralstous that Evening and found him and familey all well the 2 little children now about Twelve years old and look harty was going to school he seams to be doing well on the 23 got Mr Kirkpatricks staid with him to next Evening maid not trade went to Hugh Catrons and found his family well onley he has the fever & ague a little seams to be doing well on sonday morning left for Brother Johns a long crooked lonesome Road for one day pasing a watering place some Improved on Beaver dam creek and forded Duck River and got to Brother Johns a little before dark found all well but his wife and she was verry sick spent the next day with him his mills is fine but the cuntry is mitey Ruff on Tuesday the 27th started for home and got to Ellason on harper and got home on the 28th Found every thing geting along midling well I was intirely satisfied with Trip altho I had effected nothing
I began to cut wheat on the 5th and has bean cuting nearley every day since and it began to rain and stoped me from giting done my wheat is verry good and my Ry is the best I have ever had and I am determined to sow more than I have ever sowed I think we would dou better to Raise Ry to fead horses on if it would do as well every year as I think it will this some of my Ry and wheat will make near twenty Bushels to the acre I lefted your note to A G Payn $70,,50 Intr 1.75 and it was hard for me to spare the mone so much neded to Settle my own debts
